trial_identification.studytitle: Psychometric properties of pain and physical functioning outcome measures in patients with diabetic neuropathic pain.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Investigating the psychometric properties of patient-reported outcome measures in individuals with chronic diabetic neuropathic pain: a prospective longitudinal cohort study protocol

interventions.interventions: The status of pain intensity and physical functioning will be observed in participants with diabetic peripheral neuropathic pain via two questionnaires (Pain outcome measure: modified Brief Pain Inventory for Diabetic Neuropathic Pain (BPI-DPN) item and scale & Physical functional outcome measure: Screening of Activity Limitation & Safety Awareness scale (SALSA)). The total duration of observation will be three months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome measure-1: Modified Brief Pain Inventory- Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy Item scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Time points: at baseline and at the end of 1st and 3rd month following baseline assessment

primaryOutcome.outcome: Primary outcome measure- 2: Screening of Activity Limitation and Safety Awareness scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 1 and 3 months after baseline assessment

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Secondary Outcome measure: The Patient Global Impression of Change scale
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 1 and 3 months after baseline (Primary) assessment

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
1. Adults with a history of Diabetes; and having symptoms of neuropathic pain for > 3 months and scored 12 or more on Self-complete Leeds Assessment of Neuropathic Symptoms and Signs: (S-LANSS) will be eligible to participate in the study.
2. Participants should be able to understand English and provide informed consent to participate.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Participants who are unable to comprehend and record outcome measure data will be excluded.

trial_design.statisticalmethods:
Number of participants: 80
Test-retest reliability: Intraclass correlation coefficient
Validity testing: Pearsons correlation coefficient
Responsiveness and for calculating minimal clinical important differences: Anchor based approach will be used (sensitivity and specificity approach, within patients score change, and between patients score change)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will investigate the psychometric properties in specific pain intensity and physical functional outcome measures in adults with chronic diabetic Neuropathic pain (NeP). Specifically this study aims to: 1. Investigate the test-retest reliability of modified Brief Pain Inventory Diabetic Neuropathic Pain (BPI-DPN) scale and Screening of Activity Limitation and Safety Awareness (SALSA) scale in adults with chronic diabetic neuropathic pain (NeP). 2. Longitudinally investigate the responsiveness: Minimal Clinically important change (MCIC) of BPI-DPN and SALSA in adults with chronic diabetic NeP. 3. Observe the nature of relationship between pain intensity (BPI-DPN) and physical functioning (SALSA) outcome measures in adults with chronic diabetic NeP.
